text: Hearing is about done. Stone is just signing a document. We have a Nov. 5 trial date, plus a bunch of other important dates for filings. The longtime Trump associate remains gagged from talking about his case but wasn't jailed or given any other penalties.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Jackson sets briefing schedule. Stone's motions to dismiss due April 12. Opposition briefs from government due May 3, with Stone's reply due on May 17.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Both Mueller/government and Roger Stone lawyers say Nov. 5 is OK for trial. Jackson says that'll be the date. She expects about two weeks for the trial.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Jackson says she's looking to start Roger Stone's trial on Nov. 5.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Jeannie Rhee says government began discovery production to Roger Stone's lawyers in the first week of February, with three "significant productions" totaling 9 terabytes of data.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Jackson says "most prudent thing" to do today is to set the schedule ahead for the Stone case.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson signals she's not going to be penalizing Roger Stone on the gag order compliance issue. “I don’t intend to dwell on it this morning,” she says. Notes he'll be signing a doc when he leaves the courtroom today.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: "All rise!" We are underway in the Roger Stone status hearing.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Stone's attorneys said they couldn’t give list all motions yet bc they were sifting through materials shared by gov, including 2.2M pp of "Load Ready" data and another 4.5 TBs of "Non-Load" ready additional data "that is in the process of being filtered and prepared for review."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Also expected to go over Roger Stone’s defense motion plans. His lawyers told the court last week they were considering filing a motion claiming “selective or vindictive prosecution” and another motion to dismiss the indictment “regarding error in the grand jury proceeding.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: We're expected to get a trial date today for Stone. Mueller’s team has said it needs 5-8 days to make its case, including defense cross-examine of gov witnesses. It also  requested starting in Oct. at a previous hearing; while Judge Jackson said she'd been eyeing July or Aug.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Paul Manafort’s prison sentence was upped to seven-and-a-half years on Wednesday morning, bringing an end to Robert Mueller’s most public legal battle and capping a spectacular fall for the globetrotting GOP consultant and former chairman of the Trump campaign. @politico
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson working her way up to the sentence. She's now ticking through how he got to the Alexandria jail via witness tampering and Manafort's own requests to be moved from a different Virginia jail too far from the court and restrictions on his ability to prep for trial.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson alludes to Manafort's apparent Trump pardon play by noting his recent argument about Mueller being the only impetus for him facing charges. "It was being repeated for some other audience. So I probably don’t need to say too much about it."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson not happy with Manafort allegedly fudging so many things during course of his legal proceedings and takes swipe at the current state of affairs. "It’s all very problematic to me because court is one of those places where facts still matter," she says.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Jackson skewers Manafort for cheating taxpayers. “Why? Not to support a family but to sustain a lifestyle at the most opulent and extravagant level" and to buy "more houses than one man can enjoy, more suits than one man can wear.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Also this: “His life is not over.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson: “This defendant is not public enemy No. 1 but he’s not a victim either.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: "All rise!" We are back. Sentencing to come for Manafort soon.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Courtroom getting quiet but still waiting Judge Jackson's return. Manafort is seated in his wheelchair closest to the judge, with his back to the Mueller prosecutors.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Here's our rolling update from Judge Jackson's courtroom - 'I am sorry': Manafort pleads for mercy ahead of second sentencing https://politi.co/2TQiUO0  @politico
author: dsamuelsohn

text: More Manafort: "While I can not undo the past I can ensure the future will be very different.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: More of the Manafort apology: "“The person who I have been described as in public and in this courtroom is not someone that I recognize....Let me be very clear I accept the responsibility for the acts that have caused me to be here today."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson calls recess so she can consider what's been said today. Back around 11:15 or so, she says.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Manafort notes last week's statement didn't come across as he intended and apologies: "I am sorry for what I have done and for all the activities that have gotten us here today."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Manafort about to address the court. Reading from written statement again.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Manafort attorney Kevin Downing asks Judge Jackson to consider "media frenzy" around Mueller as she considers sentencing & the "harshness" it's created for his client: "But for a short stint as a campaign manager in a  presidential election, I don't think we’d be here today."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Kevin Downing tells Judge Jackson that Manafort will soon speak to the court about the crimes he's being sentenced for.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Weissmann still working methodically to present all of Manafort's crimes, including violations of foreign lobbying registration disclosure and money laundering.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: We’re now at the point where Judge Jackson invites both sides to talk about appropriate sentence for Manafort. Weissmann going first.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson still working through federal sentencing guidelines and whether to give Manafort any of the enhancements he has requested for his acceptance of responsibility and his leadership role in the crimes.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Jackson notes Manafort facing a maximum of 10 years for all the crimes he pleaded guilty to in DC, which includes secretly stashing fortunes in foreign bank accounts & avoiding millions in taxes, acting as an unregistered foreign agent for Ukraine & witness tampering.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson talking through how she's not here for "review or revision" of the nearly 4-year sentence Manafort got in Virginia. She lists the crimes he's getting sentenced for here in DC.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson ticks through a list of letters she's got on Manafort's behalf, notes she read them all.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: "All rise!" Judge Amy Berman Jackson has taken her seat at the bench and  Manafort sentencing Part II has begun.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Unlike his sentencing in Virginia, where he had to wear his green Alexandria jail prison jumpsuit last week, Manafort is in the DC federal courtroom today wearing a dark suit. He's still in a wheelchair.

text: A busy day in court - here’s the latest reflow of our story on Judge Jackson slapping Roger Stone with a gag order @POLITICO w/ ⁦@joshgerstein⁩ & ⁦@matthewchoi2018⁩
author: dsamuelsohn

text: NEW: Judge Jackson puts the Roger Stone gag order in writing. Here’s a screenshot of the most important part.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Hearing adjourned. Stone is not going to jail. But he won't be talking about the case anymore. Nor will his surrogates. He can send emails to raise money and say he's pleading not guilty. But that's about it.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson says any more mess ups and Stone may be sent to jail. "I want to be clear today. I gave you a second chance. But this is not baseball. There will not be a third chance."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson in backing up the gag order, which limits Stone from speaking at all about the case: "So no, Mr. Stone I'm not giving you another chance. I have serious doubts about whether you've learned any lesson at all."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson gags Roger Stone.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson notes Stone is charged for witness intimidation. Says his release "poses a danger" to the community. Decision TK.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson not taking Stone's apology. Says it looks like it came from his lawyers: “So thank you, but the apology rings quite hollow.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson: "There's nothing ambiguous about crosshairs.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson is giving Roger an earful.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: "All rise" We are back in session.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Still in recess: Stone seated and chatting with his lawyers while we wait for Judge Jackson.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson adjourns for 15-minute recess and will come back with her decision. "I'm going to take a break to try to absorb this," she says.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: DOJ prosecutor Jonathan Kravis is now urging Judge Jackson to slap a gag order on Stone.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Rogow says Stone's conditions for release shouldn't be changed. This is a "lesson" Stone has learned. “This is the only thing that has come up, that’s caused him and all of us, that brings us to the court...this afternoon."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Stone says he didn't realize the crosshairs was in the photo until he got a call from a reporter.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: US asst attorney Jonathan Kravis finished with his questions of Stone.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Stone can't say who had his phone on Monday. "My house is like a headquarters. I have many volunteers." Judge Jackson, "I thought you said you had 5." Stone replies, "5 is a lot for coming and going."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson and Mueller prosecutors pushing Stone to explain his other media statements, to InfoWars and others, about the Instagram post.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Stone says he's asked his volunteers who was it who got the at-issue image. "Nobody will own up to it," he says.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Stone says he had multiple images of the judge on his phone: "I erased all the images of your honor because I didn’t’ want to make the same mistake twice."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Stone: "I recognize that I let the court down. I let you down. I let myself down. I let my family down. I let my attorneys down. I can only say I'm sorry. it was a momentary lapse in judgement. Perhaps I talk too much."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Stone: "I am kicking myself over my own stupidity but not more than my wife is kicking me.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Roger Stone is taking the witness stand.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Rogow says he's OK with Stone being questioned by Mueller/DOJ and by the judge. He'll be under oath.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson reads from Stone lawyers' initial brief opposing gag order, asks, "How exactly does he pursue his livelihood?"
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Rogow: He wants to put Stone on the stand to explain himself. Judge Jackson says she'll let him do that.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Jackson asks Rogow to stay at the lectern. Shows him Exhibit 1, the Stone Instagram post.

text: A federal judge poised to issue Michael Flynn’s sentence on Tuesday blasted the former Trump national security adviser for lying to the FBI and questioned whether special counsel Robert Mueller’s prosecutors could have tried him for treason. @politico http://ow.ly/wPTF30n29Cu
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Gen. Flynn has returned to the courtroom with his attorneys. Still waiting for the recess to end.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: People are milling around in Judge Sullivan's chambers right now during the recess. I can see van Grack and Zainab Naeem Ahmad talking together at the prosecution table. Flynn's table remains empty.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan has recessed Flynn's sentencing hearing until 12:30 p.m. to give Flynn and his lawyers a chance to rethink everything that's been discussed so far today w/ respect to postponing this entire proceeding.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan asks Mueller prosecutors if Flynn could have been indicted for treason. Van Grack replies, "That was not something we were considering at the time, charging the defendant."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan: "All along you were an unregistered agent of a foreign country while serving as the national security adviser of the president of the United States. ... Arguably that undermines everything that flag over here stands for. Arguably, you sold your country out."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan again offering Flynn a chance to push off today's sentencing until his cooperation is over. “Do you want to postpone this and come back at some later point and I don’t know what that point will be. That’s fine with me.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Mueller prosecutor van Grack says Flynn played a cooperative role (and could have been indicted) in the case unsealed Monday against 2 former business partners who were charged with failing to register as foreign agents as they covertly lobbied on behalf of Turkey.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: “This is a very serious offense,” Judge Sullivan said, noting Flynn’s crime involved a high-ranking official of the government making false statements to the FBI “while on the physical premise of the White House.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Mueller prosecutor Brandon van Grack, when asked by the judge if Flynn is still helping the special counsel, “It remains a possibility that Gen. Flynn is continuing to cooperate at this point.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan stumbles in pronouncing POTUS's Mar-a-Lago club when ticking through the facts of Flynn's guilty plea.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan sends Flynn and his attorneys back to their seats as he now turns to talking about the initial guilty plea.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan once again runs through with Flynn whether he wants to w/d his guilty plea. Again, Flynn says, "I would like to proceed your honor." And the judge announces he'll accept the plea.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan said he had some "concerns" based on Flynn's pre-sentencing filing. ”I cannot recall any incident in which the court has accepted a plea of guilty from someone who maintained he was not guilty and I don’t intend to start today.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan offers Flynn a chance to postpone this sentencing hearing to rethink his guilty plea. Flynn replies, "“I appreciate that, but no your honor.”
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan asking Flynn whether he wants to change his guilty plea in light of 302s and other new info. He has declined.
author: dsamuelsohn

text: Judge Sullivan notes he's not the original judge who took Flynn's guilty plea. The also says to the lawyers to let him know if he accidentally broaches sealed info. "I don’t want to unintentionally say something that something that should not be revealed on the public docket."
author: dsamuelsohn

text: "All rise." And the Flynn sentencing is underway. Judge Sullivan takes his seat at the bench.
author: dsamuelsohn
